verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Once again, God initiates the message, emphasizing that this is not Ezekiel's own idea but divinely revealed (see also Ezek. 1:3; 3:16).

verses.text: Son of man, this is what the Lord GOD says to the land of Israel: 'The end! The end has come upon the four corners of the land.'
verses.comment: The repetition of 'the end' is emphatic, showing the certainty and completeness of the coming judgment. The four corners allude to totality (Isa. 11:12), indicating all Israel is included.

verses.text: Now the end is upon you, and I will send my anger against you. I will judge you according to your ways and bring all your abominations upon you.
verses.comment: The language highlights both God’s justice and the personal responsibility of each generation (cf. Deut. 28:20; Rom. 2:6).

verses.text: My eye will not spare you, nor will I have pity. I will bring your ways upon you, and your abominations will be in your midst. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: The refrain 'then you will know that I am the LORD' is a major theme in Ezekiel, aiming to bring about true knowledge and worship of God (cf. Ex. 7:5; John 17:3).

verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: Disaster after disaster—behold, it comes!
verses.comment: The phrase 'disaster after disaster' (literally 'one evil, behold, another') communicates compounding calamity—a warning of coming judgment.

verses.text: An end has come, the end has come! It has awakened against you. Behold, it has come!
verses.comment: Repetition here is poetic, increasing the sense of urgency. The end is not arbitrary, but corresponds to God’s justice (see 2 Pet. 3:9-10).

verses.text: Your doom has come to you, O inhabitant of the land. The time has come, the day is near—trouble and not joyful shouting upon the mountains.
verses.comment: 'Doom' also translates as 'the turn' or 'circle,' a poetic word for fate. Contrast with feasts on the mountains, now replaced by mourning (Isa. 16:10).

verses.text: Soon I will pour out my fury on you, and I will finish venting my anger against you. I will judge you according to your ways, and will bring all your abominations upon you.
verses.comment: God’s wrath is specifically directed at sin—implying the need for true repentance and conversion (cf. Rom. 2:5).

verses.text: My eye will not spare, nor will I have pity. I will bring your ways upon you, and your abominations will be among you. Then you will know that it is I, the LORD, who strikes.
verses.comment: God stresses perfect justice and his own sovereignty. This prepares the way for an even deeper knowledge of God in the new covenant (Jer. 31:33-34).

verses.text: Behold, the day! Behold, it comes! The doom has gone out. The rod has blossomed, pride has budded.
verses.comment: The 'rod' here may allude to both Aaron’s rod (sign of authority and judgment) and instruments of discipline God uses (cf. Isa. 10:5). Pride is the root of the rebellion.

verses.text: Violence has grown into a rod of wickedness. None of them will remain: none of their people, none of their crowd, nor anything of theirs. Nothing of value will be found among them.
verses.comment: Without righteousness, Israel loses its inheritance and blessings, pointing to the need for an enduring people of God (see Rom. 11:15-21).

verses.text: The time has come, the day draws near. Let neither the buyer rejoice, nor the seller mourn, for wrath is upon all their multitude.
verses.comment: Economic transactions are meaningless in the face of final judgment—temporal concerns are eclipsed by the eternal (Mark 8:36).

verses.text: For the seller shall not return to what is sold, even though they are still alive. For the vision concerning their entire multitude will not be reversed, and because of their sins, none will preserve their lives.
verses.comment: The irrevocable nature of judgment is illustrated—underscoring the seriousness of mortal sin and the need for authentic conversion.

verses.text: They have blown the trumpet and made everything ready, but no one goes to battle, for my wrath is upon all their multitude.
verses.comment: Human preparations are futile in the face of divine wrath. This foreshadows the theme of spiritual preparedness in the New Testament (Matt. 25:1-13).

verses.text: The sword is outside, and pestilence and famine are within. Whoever is in the field will die by the sword, and whoever is in the city—famine and pestilence will devour him.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is inescapable. The sword, famine, and plague are common symbols of comprehensive divine judgment (see Lev. 26:25-26; Rev. 6:8).

verses.text: If any of them survive, they will flee to the mountains, like doves of the valleys, all of them moaning, each for their own sin.
verses.comment: The survivors’ mourning 'each for their own sin' points to a step toward individual confession and true repentance—a pattern that develops more fully in Christian life.

verses.text: All hands will hang limp and every knee will be as weak as water.
verses.comment: This vivid image reappears in apocalyptic texts, symbolizing utter fear and helplessness before the Lord (cf. Phil. 2:10).

verses.text: They will put on sackcloth, and horror will cover them. Shame will be on every face, and baldness on all their heads.
verses.comment: Sackcloth and baldness are signs of extreme mourning. Outward actions express interior contrition—a principle continued in sacramental confession.

verses.text: They will cast their silver into the streets, and their gold will become as filth. Their silver and gold cannot deliver them in the day of the LORD’s wrath. They will not satisfy their hunger or fill their stomachs, for it was the stumbling block of their iniquity.
verses.comment: Wealth is useless in salvation—pointing to the enduring spiritual riches given in true worship (cf. Matt. 6:19-21; 1 Pet. 1:18-19).

verses.text: As for the beauty of his ornament, he set it in majesty; but they made the images of their abominations and detestable things in it. Therefore, I have made it an unclean thing to them.
verses.comment: The people corrupted what was meant to be for holy worship by using it for idolatry. The pattern of sanctifying creation for worship reaches fulfillment in the true Temple (see John 2:19-21).

verses.text: I will give it into the hands of foreigners as plunder, and to the wicked of the earth as spoil, and they shall profane it.
verses.comment: Loss of the Temple’s treasures illustrates both temporal and spiritual dangers facing a people who abandon right worship (see Lam. 1:10).

verses.text: I will turn my face from them, and they will defile my treasured place; violent men will enter it and defile it.
verses.comment: God’s 'treasured place' points to the special dwelling of God with his people. The New Covenant points to Christ and the Church as the new and everlasting temple (Eph. 2:19-22; John 1:14).

verses.text: Make the chain, for the land is full of bloody crimes and the city is full of violence.
verses.comment: Chains represent coming captivity due to the people's sins. The emphasis on justice against bloodshed and violence is a constant in God’s law (Gen. 9:6; Matt. 26:52).

verses.text: So I will bring the worst of the nations, and they will take possession of their houses. I will put an end to the pride of the mighty, and their holy places will be profaned.
verses.comment: The theme of the worst nations as judgment is recurrent (cf. Deut. 28:49). This reveals dependence not on earthly power but on humble faith.

verses.text: When anguish comes, they will seek peace, but there will be none.
verses.comment: True peace cannot be found apart from God's will—this anticipates the promise of peace as found in Christ (John 14:27; Phil. 4:7).

verses.text: Disaster will follow disaster, and rumor will be upon rumor. They will seek a vision from the prophet, but the law will perish from the priest and counsel from the elders.
verses.comment: Spiritual leadership collapses in Israel as a result of sin, highlighting the tragic need for constant, living guidance—a role fulfilled in continuity through apostolic succession.

verses.text: The king will mourn, the prince will be clothed with despair, and the hands of the people of the land will tremble. I will deal with them according to their ways, and judge them according to their own judgments. Then they will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Every class—kings, princes, people—faces God’s justice. This foreshadows the universal call to repentance, fulfilled in the invitation to the body of Christ.
